title: Before 19 June 2021, will the end-of-day closing value for the Turkish lira against the U.S. dollar exceed 9.00?
preds: Need a 3.6% move in next couple days. Holding at 1%

"Turkey’s lira fell against the dollar ahead of a central bank decision on interest rates. The central bank’s monetary policy committee is holding a monthly meeting in Ankara to decide whether to lower its benchmark rate of 19 percent after inflation slowed unexpectedly.
The lira was trading down 0.4 percent at 8.63 per dollar at noon local time in Istanbul. The central bank was due to announce its decision at 2 p.m.
The central bank will leave interest rates at 19 percent, according to a Reuters poll of economists published on Friday. All 19 respondents predicted no change."
https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkish-lira-weakens-ahead-central-bank-meeting-interest-rates If they dare to lower the interest rates, there will be the methaphorical "blood on the streets". "The Institute of International Finance (IIF), an association representing the global finance industry, has set a fair value for the lira of 9.5 per dollar, citing Turkey’s current account deficit and an exodus of foreign portfolio investment."
https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-debt/indebted-turkish-firms-left-exposed-weak-policy-fed-taper-fitch
My 8 ball says, "Don't Count on it."

It's unrealistic at the moment, but it appears the market is quite nervous ahead of the Putin-Biden summit with respects to Turkey as a NATO member country. https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkish-lira-falls-after-erdogan-tells-biden-position-s-400s-unchanged It appears the bears are back in the game.
10% move needed over one week. No major catalysts I can think of.
time is on their side. Need a 4.5% move at some point in next 11 days. About a one standard deviation move, downgrading probability a bit but crowd still way over confident in my view

8.7305 at the time of writing.
Only 3% to go and a higher close within exactly two weeks. Turkey now has the fifth highest total case count of SARS-CoV-2 in the world (nearly 5.264mn cases, which likely is an understatement...) and tourism as a key sector for bringing ForEx into the countrywill be devastated for a second year in a row.

my forecast is still a massive outlier but now less than 5% away. Today it is reported Erdogan wants interest rate cuts which has put extra pressure on the lira. almost every month there is political interference in the finances which pushes the lira down. it is still a good bet to get to 9:1 just whether it will happen in 19 days. happy to be out there on this one...

Lira slumps to 8.67: https://www.forexlive.com/centralbank/!/turkish-lira-slammed-to-a-record-low-against-the-dollar-after-erdogan-rate-cut-threat-20210601. Now need just less than a 3% down move to get to 9, but only two weeks to go. Feels like a bit less than a 1SD possibility

"MEPs said Turkey had distanced itself from European values and continued backsliding in the field of rule of law. They blamed Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan for his authoritarian moves. But the European Parliament say accession negotiations should be formally suspended if Turkey does not change course. "

Wild swings in EUR/TRY in European trading, with half an hour to go until American trading opens. It could happen this week.

Spikes that high happen 2 times a year. It's a 4-day-ish event when it happens. So we have ~90 segments a year with 2 events a year.
Probability of it not happening is 89/90 in each period = 0.98888888. There are 8 of these 4-day periods left. .98888888^8 = 0.9145. So, 9% chance of event.
It'll likely happen, just maybe not in time...
Rethinking, near record 8.58 high, deferring interest rates not enough and bank running low on muscle (cash) to sustain this, over 100 billion dollars this experiment.

8.50TRY per USD today, time of writing. Nearly six per cent of devaluation to go, one closing day lower. +0.8% EUR/TRY after half a trading day, means within a week the question could resolve "Yes", if the crisis in Turkey escalates.
Maybe the Israel/Hamas crisis, which probably hasn't seen its peak yet, will be a key factor, since there's a lot of uncertainty in the region (Turkey has an ambition of being a regional (super) power...).

The replacement of the CBRT Governor points towards weaker TRY going forward. Also as far as I understand the question if on any day the USDTRY rate exceeds 9.00 then it will count. So this is like a knock-out option.

Reacting to governor firing / big move. Feels like it still needs something else to tip it over bit still plenty of time for that
Mkssd new governor being hired. So decreasing my jump from 70 to 25
Lira is potentially recovering from two big shocks of change in financial leadership. Will there be more?
Point gun at foot, pull trigger, then do it again.

I had previously misread the question. I thought it said on June 19, but in fact it’s just saying st any point before June 19 will that happen. Lira trading at 8.28, so we are just talking about a 8% move, which is about a 0.5 standard deviation event, which brings the likelihood to 31%. Added to this I was thinking about the returns in the forward market when this is really about the spot market. Just looking at the interest rate diffeeentials, the lira is discounted to fall about 15% per year. At the same time my personal view is that the current move is overdone. On that last point, GDP adjusted currency is one of the cheapest in the world. The question is what will bring that back. Tourism is one obvious answer, but Europe’s vaccine rollout is slowing. 
https://www.economist.com/big-mac-index

~7.5% of devaluation and a daily closing left to go.

The Turkish Lira has weakened from around 3.0 to currently 8.08 in just 5 years. Previous moves by Erdogan to control the Central Bank and force lower interest rates have been followed by Lira weakness, just as we witness in the previous week. However, 9.00 is stil far away and a lot of bad news is already priced in the Lira. Reaching 9 would require more time time just 3 months from now, in my opinion.

Firing of the most recent central banker over increasing interest rates has thrown markets into disarray.  It’s not likely to get resolved soon.  Markets are spooked now because the president fired a central banker who was implementing good monetary, and he was fired it seems because the president does not believe in that monetary policy.  When politicians start imposing their own views outside the experts investors lose trust which leads to volatility.  Exchange rate is already over 8.  9 is going to happen.
Rethinking my view that interest cuts necessary for this to resolve yes. Some thinking 10 by end of 2021 a serious possibility.
3/26 closed above 8 to the $, things are not going to improve with the new governor, I am afraid.

Yesterday i went from 25 to 10 because lira seemed to be holding below 8. Well, that was short. Going back to 50.  Thw lira could pop if the turks decide to convert npw in advance of the inevitable currency controls.

The new Central Bank Governor, Sahap Kavcıoğlu, has publicly positioned himself as a man who believes low interest combats inflation (1), but has reiterated since entering office that "policy would not change any time soon and depend on inflation" (2). Given the Fitch's threat to downgrade Turkey's rating (1), if there is any indication of a cut to interest rates, or any unusual action from Kavcıoğlu, it wouldn't be surprising to see the lira screaming past 9 to 1. 1. https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/fitch-signals-possible-turkey-downgrade-after-central-bank-chief-sacked
2. https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/confusion-grips-turkish-markets-central-141941403.html

Lira will be down, Turkish stocks will be down, but this may be a long slide before it hits 9 to the $ - exiting positions causes scramble for lira in short term. Bloomberg 3/23
"Violent swings in Turkish markets have been unleashed this week after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan unexpectedly fired his central bank chief, sowing uncertainty about the country’s future monetary policy. Among investors, there are concerns that the central bank has lost credibility, and with inflation accelerating to almost 16% in February, the economy faces severe challenges."
"As investors hunt for lira to close the swaps, some of the demand showed up in the local spot market. The currency was only 1% weaker at 7.8808 against the dollar on Tuesday -- a sign of stability after yesterday’s 8% plunge. "Still, many analysts are unconvinced that the losses are over. Renaissance Capital predicts the currency could slide a further 12% by year-end, while Commerzbank AG expects it to reach 10 per dollar."

recent firing of central bank boss rattled the markets and rate spiked to over 8 before settling back to 7.89 today. now only need 14% devaluation to get to 9. given the highly political nature of the hire/fire process the risk is more likely to the downside of the lira.

bne IntelliNews Editor's Picks --   TURKEY INSIGHT: Frantic defence of lira’s 8.00 line as foreign investors scramble to offload all Turkish papers
It's now official: Turkey has the least attractive bonds in the world. The meltdown continues apace with investors offloading Turkish obligations in a frantic defence of the TRY8 to the dollar line that they have already lost. The central bank has already run down its reserves by some $100bn defending the currency even before the well respected Naci Agbal was sacked as governor of the central bank at the weekend. We have a second piece reporting that the nominally robust Turkish banking sector is now under threat too as it is buffeted by the crashing currency. Turkey’s banking sector is generally considered to be fairly robust after deep “never-again” reforms were made following a 2001 bank crisis, but even the modern banks are struggling to cope with what has been going on in the last few days. I think the phrase “massive mismanagement” aptly sums up the situation. One piece of good news is that contagion to the rest of the region looks like it will be limited.

Going to ride the next month in the safety of 25%. Which is ahead of crowd.  The new governor is going to be loose with rates. There are only 2 months left on the question, so maybe lkra will not cross 9 when question closes. But it will cross this year if rates are loosened.
Fired central banker.  Lira was 6.5 and shot up to 8.0.  Need to get a new governor and then see if markets believe he will restrain erdogan.

from BNE - Erdogan sacks another central banker Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sacked his central bank governor Naci Agbal, who was doing a good job, and replaced him with Shihab Kavcioglu, who is expected to do what he is told. The lira is already in meltdown and Turkey is sliding over the edge of the abyss. Agbal managed to turn the Turkish boat around during his four (!) months on the job. A 200bp rate hike changed the lira from one of the worst performing currencies in the world to the best in the last three months. But as you probably know Erdogan hates interest rate hikes as he believes they cause inflation (opposite to everyone else). We are following this story closely and our Turkey correspondent Akin Nazli, who predicted the start of the latest FX catastrophe well before it happened, has blogged about some of the consequences.

The Turkish Lira is quickly approaching its intra-day lows in European trading of 9.52 TRY versus the EURO.
Other than expected, the fault line in this type of earthquake leads along a highly politized central bank that is widely seen by politicians and the Erdogan circle as their instrument for domestic politics, and is thus incapacitated to run independent and economically sound and founded central bank policy in order to halt high and  ever faster accelerating inflation.
The current spike in devaluation is more than a short episode, it seems it's a blunt certificate of distrust and "vote-by-heels" against foreign investments in Turkey. The monetary situation is bad enough to start some domino effects within the country that could further spur crisis, and it could be a matter of days only now until this question resolves "YES".

The new Central bank head believes cutting interest rates will arrest inflation. I think the cooldown in the spot rates happened after the Kavicioglu clarified that there won't be any drastic measures in the near term. The next central bank meeting on 15th April will be key to watch. Having a higher estimate than the crowd for now as there are 2 other factors to consider  
Dwindling turkish Fx reserves
Sharp Yield spikes in US which is bad for emerging markets.
The move tonight looks overdone, but at 8.5 now it’s just a 5% move between now and June, which is less than a one standard deviation event.

Even during the rapid drop of the Turkish lira, it took 9 months to drop 20%. 
Currently, at 7.38, less than 6 months to go. I don't believe Turkish lira depreciation will accelerate any further. On the contrary, I believe in reversal to the mean, i.e. the Lira will either depreciate slower or in fact will appreciate.

12/29 = 7.3937TRY / $ over the last five years the Turkish lira has fallen from 2.8TRY/$ to the current value.  The lowest point was Nov 6 2020 when it was about 8.5TRY/$. It has strengthened since then, under the guidance of a new finance minister (not the President's son-in-law). Currency usually moves slowly, even the Turkish lira's fall was not monotonic. While it could easily touch 8.5TRY/$ again, it will likely continue to respond to the new finance minister and not leap to 9TRY/$.
Due to the short term nature of this question and honeymoon period for the new finance minister I find it doubtful it to drop to 9TRY/$. NYT, Nov. 8, 2020, just after the lira crashed. "Mr. Erdogan has appointed Naci Agbal, a former finance minister who is seen as a loyal but capable manager, to head the central bank."  It appears they now have an adult doing the driving and road is suddenly smoother - who knew?.
Poorly run economy; new central bank head won't be able to make much progress and won't last long anyway.

According to a recent publication by FocusEconomics  "Looking ahead, the lira is expected to remain under severe pressure against the USD through next year amid lingering geopolitical tensions, unorthodox economic policy, elevated price pressures and low real interest rates, as well as eroded institutional independence. Moreover, a twin deficit and continued uncertainty surrounding the evolution of the pandemic cloud the outlook, while the U.S. elections raise further questions over Turkey’s future relationship with the superpower. FocusEconomics panelists are pessimistic on the lira’s outlook, with the panel forecasting the TRY to end 2021 at 8.20 per USD. In 2022, the lira is not expected to perform much better, ending the year at 8.37 per USD."

According to this volatility is around 15% over 6 months https://vlab.stern.nyu.edu/analysis/VOL.USDTRY%3AFOREX-R.GARCH From today to 9 is about 18% move. I know this is not 100% accurate but if I have my stats right, normal distribution should see about 70% in 1 sd of the mean, so that implies about 15% chance that it is 1 sd above the mean. I think my maths mean it should be a bit below it, but I suspect for the next 6months most distributions will be more fat tailed, so happy to go with 15% for now.

It looks as though the rate is improving from a low of 8.52 on 8 November, so I don't see it it getting much worse in the next 6 months. Historically it has never been bad enough to hit 9. https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/?symbol=TRY=

The Lira has been under pressure recently but so has the US dollar. I believe the dollar is at a crisis point. there's not demand for the number of treasuries US government is trying to issue. It would require a solid crisis, turbulent and chaotic circumstance over a few days, to trigger a devaluation of this scope. However, there's some constant and unforeseeable risk e.g. of natural disaster in the Mediterranean in and around Turkey and Istanbul in particular.
A major earthquake (7.5 or higher magnitude) at this time of economic weakness and public health and political crisis, which some experts view as long overdue, would create just this type of circumstance, and the question covers half a year of time.
" In detail the fault is formed of many separate segments. Movement on parts of this fault zone have been responsible for many large and damaging earthquakes. They tend to form overall westward propagating sequences that can last for many decades. The most recent sequence began with the 1939 Erzincan earthquake, continuing with major earthquakes in 1942, 1943, 1944, 1949, 1951, 1957, 1966, 1967, 1992 and two in 1999."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1668_North_Anatolia_earthquake#Tectonic_setting
"It is thought that the chain is not complete, and that an earthquake will soon strike further west along the fault – perhaps near the heavily populated city of Istanbul."
